content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, but very close to the puzzle Hidden word.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I changed my mind, i like the idea and although it's like another puzzle but the outputs are different and it's okay for two puzzles to share the same idea

I'd recommend to pay attention to some details.
1. Outputting the table doesn't make sense from practical point of view.
2. Words overlap makes the words meaningless, i.e. BARTAG, SELMARGE and others.
3. Subclass of a forementioned existing puzzle.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This is a good puzzle. But it looks too much like https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/hidden-word
It's a nice one! I hope this contribution gets approved.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea. You could make it a hard puzzle or even very hard puzzle if you are given a grid of at most 1000x1000 and k <= 100.000 words (their length sum is <= 500.000 or something). This could be solved making some observations and Hashes.

Hi Lisa - I just did both puzzles. Other than changing size to height and width, my only material change was to change my print statement. Once I had your puzzle finished, the other puzzle took me less than 2 minutes.

I have to admit that I rarely look at my output. I simply look to see if the test case turns green and I look at any debug output I'm generating. Probably not the best technique on my part, but it made these two puzzles feel almost identical.

Now that I've gone back and looked at the output, it is kind of cool to see the grids with just the found words. All Codingamers are different and this might not be unique enough to some. In this case, the opinion that I think matters the most is that of @nicola.

Hi Lisa,

For the countries test & validator you shouldn't use the special character "Ç", for the clue and the grid, it's probably best not to have to deal with that (and it's the only one) in an easy puzzle.

Goal section
* As mentioned in Rafarafa's comments, there's an existing similar puzzle. Perhaps include a link to that?

* Please mention that all unused characters should be replaced by a {{space}} character, and that trailing spaces should not be trimmed in the output.

* In order to vary a bit more, maybe in addition to hiding the unused letters, the player has to convert a used letter to lowercase if a letter is used in more than one word?

Input section
* Please change "h lines" to "Next h lines".

* Please change "Line h + 2" to "Next line".

Thanks.

Quite similar to:
https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/hidden-word

Probably fine anyway, yet I wanted to let you know that changing a couple lines of @kiwijam's pythons' top solution can solve this puzzle.
Thanks for that info.  I added a reference to it.

Thanks as always for your great feedback.  I made the small changes you suggested. 

Your suggestion about converting to lower case if used in more than one word is definitely interesting.  Do you think that would be considered an "Easy" puzzle still?

Thanks for the comment cedricdd.
Very good eye.  I see it and have now fixed :)

Thanks for the feedback, Timinator

Hopefully @nicola will see the "@" and reply with their "blessing" :)

Thanks for the approval and suggestion.

FYI, Codingame limits output to be about 1,000 characters, so that's a limiting factor.

Cool !!!!

Thanks
Thanks for the approval.  Hopefully it will drive more people to try Nicola's Hidden Word puzzle, and thus benefit everyone :)
As an approver, your opinion is important to all of us. Would you mind commenting on the similarities of the other puzzle. Thank you.
The other puzzle is a bit different, yes they are similar but this one is more visual and for an easy puzzle more interesting for beginners.

So I was going to post something in "Discussion" tab under Nicola's "Hidden Word" puzzle, so that hopefully they would see it, but there is no Discussion tab.  I am still not that great with navigating all the stuff inside Codingame... is there a way to send Nicola a direct message, or -- ????
I sent a DM in the forum.

My puzzle is a very old puzzle and it’s very similar to this one.
The difference in mine is that you have to extract the unused letters and build a word with it. Here, you just have to replace them by spaces.

Well it was messing up my regex and so the test was failing but it took me a while to understand what was going on especially since it was working locally but failing on CG.

A remark I could make about tests, I would put the grid with the Simpsons in first place as it's the smallest one, it would be the easiest to debug.
Good idea.  Done.

I think that would be somewhere between the more difficult end of "Easy" and the easier end of "Medium".

Oh, I didn't notice that the clues were given in capitalised case - please mention that in Constraints section.

Also, what does the tag of "oop" mean? That tag hasn't been used before?

"oop" was one of the choices in there already.  I assumed Object Oriented Programming.

I had made each FoundWord an object, with properties like "starting point" and direction and wordItself (or something like that).   That seemed like the most straightforward way to do it so I am thinking that qualifies as oop.

I was just trying to include something a little different -- I don't feel that strongly about though, and will remove if you think I should.

OK, please let me know when you're done updating :)

oop: CG did a tag clean-up previously; I think oop might just be some tag used before but no longer in use. It's better to use a tag in use instead.

(nothing here: https://www.codingame.com/learn/oop )

I removed "oop" :), and added "Conditions" (as that is what the medium version of this puzzle had as one of its tags)
If you have any ideas for other tags please tell me
I added something about capitalization case, but I don't love my phrasing.  Please feel free to go in and change/improve it if you like.

I like your suggestion about adding the lower case (when used more than once), but I want to think about it more.

(I am thinking maybe doing that for another version of this later.)
Not sure about using "capitalized" and "fully-capitalized" to distinguish between the two... Maybe "all-caps" instead of "fully-capitalized"?
Done :)
